 The only new thing to me was the idea of subtracting vectors. For example the top hat question was asking if you would add or subtract/which way you would subtract. However, with examples I was able to understand. I did like the breakout groups and getting to discuss with classmates. I also wish that the comment section was geared more towards questions and not comments because questions can get lost. Thanks.
 How, even with having to visualizing a resultant vector, the two addition vectors do not need to be visualized tip to tail.
 I thought today's lecture was good. One thing I'd like clarification on is vector notation if it hasn't already been specified in the question. Will you expect a specific notion? Will you expect the (i, j, k) notation or is arrow(<x,y>) acceptable too? 
 Our first lecture was not co fusing. We talked about the syllabus, how grading works, how extra credit is assigned, and what programs to install. The only confusing part is making sure we have all the software and books we need. Something that could help with that is a checklist.
 I had a bit of trouble interacting with others in the breakout rooms, but that is something I will work on improving myself. 
 I just don't understand when we subtract and don't add. I understand why we have to subtract certain ways but when do we subtract? 
 It seemed like some people didn't quite know how Tophat was going to work, and missed out on partial question points by not submitting an answer. Maybe another quick recap of the program and grading policies before starting the first question would be useful.
 I am still having some difficulties adding and subtracting vectors geometrically which also goes along with making the vector drawings for word problems. 
 Using Top Hat/getting used to using Top Hat was a bit confusing and tough. I wasn't always sure when to submit answers, how much time I had, and I had some trouble getting out of the zoom window quickly and to the Top Hat one. I think the more practice I get with it though the better I'll get at it. 
 The video was good today, and the worked out examples helped. I personally wasn't as prepared as I needed to be for class because this is my first flipped class ever. I look foreword to improving this for next class though.
 Maybe some clarification on when it is necessary to add 180 degrees to the answer of some problems and specifically how to identify when to do that both before you answer the problem and after. 
 I followed along very well in today's lecture, but I wish I had a bit more practice before answering the TOPHAT questions. I watched/did the extra problems and videos in addition to the quiz.
 A thing that confused me this lecture was how to subtract vectors. Now when I say this I am talking about the beginning of class, by the end of class I was beginning to understand through techniques like the trace method.
 Need more description about how you know what directions you draw vectors in all different cases, especially when you are trying to find the expression for a resultant using the subtraction of two other vectors. When drawing the resultant, do you always start from the first vector you drew and connect it to the last? I am very confused and others in my breakout room were too. 
 I am slightly confused about Unit Vectors. It would have been nice to have a bit more context or explanation about this topic. 
 I think it was a pretty good class, vector subtraction was a bit confusing but I think the explanation on adding vectors was great!
 In today's video lecture I struggled with figuring out when to subtract and when to add vectors. For example, in the yeti problem I did not know if you were supposed to add the two vectors or subtract them. The same goes for the Top Hat question earlier. in class regarding RA and RB. My instinct is to always add it it confuses me on when to subtract.
 Nothing from this video lecture was particularly unclear. It would be helpful to have more problems where unit vectors are used and/or examples of their overall use in physics. 
 Just needed back in the swing of all the trig functions. Haven't used them too much in about a year. 
 everything made sense, I didn't find anything confusing
 I have difficulty figuring out which direction (as in North of East or South of West) the resulting vector is pointing.
 In the Vector Basics section maybe include a position vs. time graph problem with questions related to trying to find speed and velocity in order to really highlight the difference between scalars and vectors in the scope of this class. Additionally the Adding and Subtracting Vectors by Components could use another example on how to arrange the arrows to suit a given equation when they are all out of order. (Side note: on the concept quizzes, I feel like there should be a note that you only have one opportunity to get full points, following that you'll lose points for each attempt.)
 The information was explained in an easy to understand manner. However, I would like more information on negative vectors and how they affect the problem when the resultant gets moved around. I know you said that negative vectors wouldn't be used much but I still think it was a confusing topic. Thank you!
 Something that was confusing about today's video lecture was how in some cases with inverse tangent, you must add 180 degrees to your answer. I understand that this can be seen with the graph of tangent, but I'm not sure how you know when you should trust your answer or know that u have to add 180 degrees. 
 The lecture was overall very clear. The only part I found slightly confusing was the unit vectors, specially the purpose they serve, since it is just multiplying by 1.
 The video lectures were thorough about how to do the math for vectors. The thing that is confusing was the identification of scalars and vectors specifically if scalars need units or not.

suggestion:
Summary: Students generally found the TopHat questions to be a useful tool for assessing their understanding, but some struggled with navigating the platform and submitting answers within the allotted time. A few students felt that the incorrect answers were not thoroughly explained, making it difficult for them to understand where they went wrong. Some students also expressed a desire for more practice with TopHat and clarification on the program's functionality before the first question.

Suggestions:
1. Provide more detailed explanations for incorrect TopHat answers, to help students understand where they went wrong and what they need to work on.
2. Consider offering additional practice with TopHat before the first question, to help students become more comfortable with the platform and its functionality.
3. Include a brief review or tutorial on how to navigate TopHat and submit answers within the allotted time, to help reduce student frustration and anxiety.

A few students felt that the incorrect answers were not thoroughly explained, making it difficult for them to understand where they went wrong. To improve, providing more detailed explanations for incorrect answers, offering additional practice with TopHat before the first question, and including a brief review or tutorial on how to navigate the platform and submit answers within the allotted time would be beneficial. This would help students become more comfortable with the platform and its functionality, ultimately enhancing their learning experience.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the concept of Free Body Diagrams (FBDs) to be a challenging yet interesting topic, with many appreciating the "recipe" for drawing FBDs as a helpful tool. They enjoyed applying FBDs to various problems, such as the man supporting himself on a pulley system, and found it intriguing that pulleys can reduce the force required to lift an object to half its weight. Students also appreciated learning how to rotate axes to align forces and how to redefine the system to simplify calculations. Additionally, they found the concept of tension between objects, particularly when there is acceleration, to be fascinating.
input:
The different applications of FBD to solve problems like the example of the man supporting himself on the pulley system. 
We had one of the same problems with two people pulling a rope on each side and the tension in the rope is between both of their forces
Despite this being a difficult concept, i though the man pulling himself up with a pulley was very interesting, as it shows how pulleys can be utilized in industry 
top hat
I found the fact that forces had resisting components interesting. 
drawing free body diagrams to set up equations
I found the fact that it became 2T interesting when he pulled himself up.
The “recipe” for free body diagrams. It made drawing them a lot easier.
I found it most interesting that to hold yourself still while on a pulley system, you only need to apply the force of half your weight. 
Today, I found the conceptual problem with the man pulling up with a velocity the most interesting. If you had done the problem in your mind, then you would have gotten twice the answer. 
 The pulley system/elevator problems because I find them very fun to do.
 I found the top hat questions about normal force to be most interesting 
 Top hat question where the man on the chair pulls on the rope. I thought it was an interesting real life problem to solve.
 The part that I found most interesting about today's lecture was the conceptual questions because they were tricky.
 I found the first example with the man in the chair the most interesting.  The fact that he only has to pull with half the force of gravity was intriguing. 
 free body diagrams

 I thought learning how to draw free body diagrams was interesting. I also thought that learning about how the axes can be rotated so that more of the forces line up with them was really useful and interesting. 
 three block problem
 I enjoyed learning about pushing boxes on a frictionless surface, and how a force can be applied on it. 
 You can turn external forces into internal forces 
 Break out room problems involving free body diagrams and work
 I find tension interesting. The fact that two things can way down one rope and it's the same tension fascinated me. 
 How you can change the system you analyze in the problem depending on what you want to solve for
 Free body diagrams and how acceleration works
 Physically setting up the FBDs and solving for variables was very interesting because it's like a puzzle
 That pulley systems make it easier to lift things up
 The fact that when you are on a rope and pull yourself up you only have to pull with half the force because it is 2T
 I found the ice problem interesting. It took a lot of trial and error for me to think of the correct way, but it was interesting.
 Understanding my mistakes after he went over one of the questions on top hat
 the use of free bodies to solve the atwood machine problem with forces
 Calculating tension with the diagrams? 
 Redefining the system to make calculations faster by calling several objects the system instead of just one
 The idea of changing the coordinate system to make the problem easier
 I thought that the pulley question was very interesting. I did not know that pulleys halved the amount of weight when being pulled up.
 I found the question about the ice to be pretty interesting because I haven't thought of forces in that way before. 
 I thought it was interesting that we are taking group tests I like that and the last problem was interesting I solved it wrong but it made sense after you went through the work
 I found the part where we could treat multiple objects as the same system interesting
 The coordinates of a system are changed based on the layout of the question.
 I found the practice problems in top hat most interesting because we got to work with our fellow classmates in breakout rooms.
 The free body diagrams and how they fit together for each problem
 Good thought provoking examples made me think about things
 The free body diagrams 
 I found it interesting how you can set directions to be however you like as long as you maintain consistency. 
 The clicker questions are helpful in practicing what we have learned from the lecture videos on YouTube. 
 I found the problem with the ice block to be interesting
 Tension between two objects when there is acceleration
 The tensions and the equation chains of tensions between objects were interesting.

refined_pred: REFINED SUMMARY: Students found the concept of Free Body Diagrams (FBDs) to be a challenging yet interesting topic. They appreciated the "recipe" for drawing FBDs as a helpful tool and enjoyed applying it to various problems, such as the man supporting himself on a pulley system. The concept of pulleys reducing the force required to lift an object to half its weight was a common point of interest, as it was found to be fascinating and useful in real-life scenarios. Additionally, students found the idea of rotating axes to align forces and redefining the system to simplify calculations to be valuable skills in solving problems involving FBDs, particularly when dealing with tension between objects, especially when there is acceleration.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the application of Free Body Diagrams (FBDs) to solve pulley and elevator problems to be engaging and interesting. Many appreciated the concept of using pulleys to reduce the force required to lift objects, with some noting that it can be as simple as applying half the force of one's weight. The use of FBDs to break down complex problems into manageable components was also highlighted as a valuable skill. Additionally, students found the idea of redefining the system to simplify calculations and the ability to change the coordinate system to be useful tools in solving these types of problems.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the concept of redefining systems to be a crucial aspect of solving problems in mechanics, particularly when working with pulley systems and free body diagrams. They appreciated the idea of treating multiple objects as a single system to simplify calculations and make the problem-solving process more efficient. The ability to change the coordinate system to align with the layout of the problem was also highlighted as a useful technique. Furthermore, students noted the importance of considering the direction of forces and how they interact with each other, including the concept of tension and its relationship with acceleration. Overall, redefining systems was seen as a powerful tool for tackling complex problems in mechanics.

suggestion:
SUMMARY: Students found the last question of the lecture, involving two blocks with friction and one sliding on the other, to be the most confusing. Many students struggled with understanding how to approach the problem, particularly with the free body diagrams and combining the two systems. Some students also had difficulty with determining the type of friction to use and understanding the relationship between the two blocks. Additionally, there was confusion about the equation F - fs = m2*a, with some students initially thinking it should be F - fs = 0.

Suggestions:
1. Emphasize the importance of clearly explaining the process of combining free body diagrams for multiple objects, highlighting the need to consider all forces acting on each object.
2. Provide more explicit guidance on determining the type of friction to use in different scenarios, such as when one block is sliding on another or when there is a frictionless surface involved.
3. Clarify the equation F - fs = m2*a by explaining that it represents the net force acting on the top block, and that the equation is derived from Newton's second law, rather than simply being a memorized formula.

Many students struggled with understanding how to approach the problem, particularly with combining free body diagrams for multiple objects and determining the correct type of friction to use. There was also confusion about the equation F - fs = m2*a, with some students initially thinking it should be F - fs = 0. To address these challenges, it is essential to provide clear guidance on combining free body diagrams, explicitly explaining the type of friction to use in different scenarios, and clarifying the derivation of the equation F - fs = m2*a from Newton's second law.

suggestion:
SUMMARY: Students found the concept of Free Body Diagrams (FBDs) challenging, particularly when dealing with multi-block systems and determining the forces acting on each block. Many students struggled with combining FBDs for multiple objects and identifying the correct type of friction to apply. Some students were also unsure about rearranging formulas and solving for unknown forces. However, the interactive lecture format and example problems boosted some students' confidence in understanding force problems, and the instructor's explanations were generally clear, with some students appreciating real-world examples.

Suggestions:
1. Emphasize the importance of labeling and identifying forces in FBDs, particularly for multi-block systems, as many students struggled with this concept.
2. Provide more explicit guidance on how to determine the correct type of friction (static or kinetic) to apply in different situations, as this was a common point of confusion.
3. Offer additional examples and practice problems that demonstrate how to rearrange formulas and solve for unknown forces, as this was a skill that many students struggled with.
refined_pred: REFINED SUMMARY: Students found the concept of Free Body Diagrams (FBDs) challenging, particularly when dealing with multi-block systems and determining the forces acting on each block. Many students struggled with combining FBDs for multiple objects, identifying the correct type of friction (static or kinetic) to apply, and rearranging formulas to solve for unknown forces. To improve understanding, explicit guidance on labeling and identifying forces in FBDs, determining the correct type of friction, and solving for unknown forces through formula rearrangement is necessary. Additional practice problems and examples that demonstrate these skills will aid students in developing a deeper understanding of FBDs and force problems.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the Top Hat questions to be a valuable learning tool, as they helped to solidify their understanding of the concepts covered in the lecture. Many students appreciated the real-world applications and examples used in the questions, which made the material more engaging and interesting. The concept of tension was a particular highlight, with students enjoying the examples and problems that demonstrated how tension remains constant throughout a rope, regardless of its length. Additionally, the use of reference frames and the relationship between forces, mass, and acceleration were also of interest to students. Overall, the Top Hat questions were seen as a helpful way to reinforce their understanding of the material and make it more relatable to everyday life.

Many appreciated the use of real-world examples, such as the top hat and tug of war scenarios, to illustrate how tension remains constant throughout a rope regardless of the reference frame. The idea that tension is the same everywhere in a rope, as long as it's not affected by external forces, was a recurring theme in the students' reflections. Additionally, the concept of inertial and non-inertial reference frames was also found to be interesting, with some students appreciating the comparison between the two. Overall, the students enjoyed the interactive and conceptual nature of the lecture, which helped to solidify their understanding of forces and Newton's Laws.

Suggestions:
1. Consider focusing more on the specific examples that students found most engaging, such as the top hat and tug of war scenarios, to highlight their understanding of tension in different reference frames.
2. Emphasize the importance of understanding the difference between inertial and non-inertial reference frames, as this was a key concept that students found interesting and worth exploring further.
3. Use more precise language to describe the concept of tension being the same everywhere in a rope, as long as it's not affected by external forces, to avoid potential confusion and ensure students' understanding of this key concept.
refined_pred: REFINED SUMMARY: Students found the concept of Reference Frames to be a fascinating topic, particularly in relation to tension and forces. The use of real-world examples, such as the top hat and tug of war scenarios, effectively illustrated how tension remains constant throughout a rope regardless of the reference frame. The idea that tension is the same everywhere in a rope, as long as it's not affected by external forces, was a recurring theme in the students' reflections. Additionally, the concept of inertial and non-inertial reference frames was also found to be interesting, with some students appreciating the comparison between the two. The interactive and conceptual nature of the lecture helped to solidify students' understanding of forces and Newton's Laws, particularly in the context of relative motion and the behavior of objects in different reference frames.

pred: SUMMARY: Students generally found the concept of centripetal force to be the most challenging aspect of the lecture. Many students expressed confusion regarding the direction of the acceleration vector and the role of centripetal force in circular motion. Some students struggled to understand how to apply centripetal force in various scenarios, such as the skydiver entering the ocean and the string and mass example. Additionally, students found it difficult to determine the centripetal force in certain situations and had trouble with the equations relating to circular motion. There was also a need for more clarification on the relationship between centripetal force and other forces, such as normal force and friction.
input:
Centripetal force was confusing and we spent very little time on it
I need more clarification about why the acceleration vector points in toward the center. 
Circular motion, centripetal force, equations relating to circular motion
I thought the problem with the skydiver into the ocean was confusing because there were too many variables.
The last example problem we did with the string and mass. I thought we didn't spend as much time on it as I would've liked. 
I struggled with the idea of how each variable impacts the overall equation for the drag force.
The most confusing part of the lecture was determining the centripetal force. 
Circular force was a bit confusing when dealing with acceleration. 
I was a little confused by the application of acceleration at an instant when terminal velocity changes. However, your explanation cleared it up. The application of multiple g's tripped me up and I got the practice problem incorrect as I forgot a g. 
I thought the question on terminal velocity was confusing. I was confused on how to set up the equation so that all the unknown variables would end up cancelling.
 I think it was tough to conceptualize some of the drag force problems. Although it's not going to be a heavy focus for the exam, I would've liked to connect more drag force problems to conceptual ideas.
 I found the example problem where the guy hits the water very confusing because of dealing with two different  densities. 
 What was confusing about this lecture was what forces can be considered a centripetal force.  I saw that soletimes it can be the normal force or some other force.
 Circular motion/centripetal force caused by friction
 The example involving the acceleration and drag force on the jumper in the ocean.
 How circular motion works, and how the forces interact.
 Circular motion and how objects move around the circle
 The problem where the person was hitting the water confused me... I thought that because they were entering the water then mg would no longer be acting on them and the only force acting would be drag force
 The explanation of deriving the equations was confusing because it moved very quickly.
 The terminal velocity question with the difference in air and water density was challenging to see at first. 
 I was confused on the units for drag force 
 Today's lesson was not unclear or confusing. The only thing that could have been explained more in depth is centripetal force.
 I am still unclear about terminal velocity and when it is used. 
 the lesson moved really fast for such a complicated topic. deriving the equations was confusing and there weren't enough examples or applications to understand the formulas
 i found the centripetal problems a little confusing today. i think I just would like to see it more. besides that it was good. 
 A hard thing to understand is when a terminal velocity begins and ends when entering or exiting different substances.
 The first example of the terminal velocity and the acceleration before the man contacts the water.
 I felt that the first group problem was confusing but once we went over it I understood it better 
 I don't get how velocity changes when you switch between materials.
 Not too confused, just a bit worried about the exam next week.
 How the drag coefficient density of air and water can be in the same equation simultaneously 
 circular motion was barely even taught, especially the net force portion 
 On the first top hat group question finding the equation and what cancelled out 
 I think more explanation should be there for the top hat examples. I was confused at a few steps.
 Normal force on the top of a hill
 I thought the last two top hat questions were confusing 
 Trying to solve a problem with very to no numbers given and having to figure out the algebra and forces 
 The problem with sonic going around in a circle confused me because it i didn't understand why it wasn't gravity 
 Tension problems could use some more examples like like a ball on a string moving in a circular path what is theta if given length of string, mass, and r maybe.
 the difference between uniform and nonuniform circular motion
 Nothing was really confusing in today's lecture
 Drag force, in particular, knowing when to substitute
 Figuring out how to do the pendulum because the wording of the question didn't make it obvious to me
 I'm confused on how centripetal force isn't an actual force.
 the effect of density on the terminal velocity
 Some of the components of drag force are a little confusing because I'm not totally sure how they all affect the overall drag.
 I would like more details on combining circular motion with free body diagrams in three dimensions, and I would like to know how much we need to know about doing derivatives of various equations.
 I could not understand the example with the puck spinning on a table holding up a weight. How does that work?
 The drag force formula was confusing. I guess this is just because we haven't seen many of the things in it before. I'm just a little unclear as to what the units are for each one.

suggestion:
Suggestions:

1.  To make the summary more concise, consider combining similar points into a single sentence. For example, the multiple mentions of "confusion" regarding the in-class activity could be condensed into a single sentence, such as "Students found the in-class activity on the weighted decision matrix to be confusing, with unclear instructions on what to complete and how to distinguish between the criteria and metrics sections."
2.  To improve the summary's focus on the topic, consider removing or rephrasing sentences that mention unrelated topics, such as the due date of assignment 18 or the instructor's presence in breakout rooms. This will help maintain a clear and focused summary.
3.  To enhance the summary's clarity, consider reorganizing the sentences to group related ideas together. For example, the summary could start by highlighting the positive aspects of the in-class activity, followed by the challenges and areas of confusion. This will create a more balanced and organized summary.
refined_pred: REFINED SUMMARY: Students generally found the in-class activity on the weighted decision matrix (WDM) to be confusing, with unclear instructions on what to complete and how to distinguish between the criteria and metrics sections. Some students also struggled with understanding the xsl file format, determining specific numbers for metrics, and the process of testing prototypes. However, many appreciated the clear explanation of the WDM concept, and a few found the activity straightforward.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the topic of histograms and graphs to be the most interesting part of the lecture, with many highlighting the importance of understanding when to use different types of graphs for various data sets, including numerical and nominal data. They appreciated the use of visual aids, such as flowcharts, to help distinguish between graph types and the hands-on experience of creating and formatting histograms in Excel. Many students enjoyed the breakout room discussions, where they could collaborate with their peers and ask questions, and appreciated the instructor's availability to provide guidance and support. Overall, students found the topic of histograms and graphs to be engaging and practical, with many seeing the value in applying these skills to real-world data analysis.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on Excel engaging and informative, particularly when it came to learning about histograms and their applications. Many appreciated the hands-on experience of creating and formatting histograms in Excel, as well as the group discussions and breakout sessions that allowed for collaboration and clarification of concepts. Students also valued the review of different graph types and when to use them, with the histogram flow chart being a helpful tool in understanding these concepts. Overall, students expressed enthusiasm for learning Excel and its capabilities, citing its potential to efficiently analyze and visualize data.

pred: SUMMARY: Students generally found the breakout rooms to be the most interesting and engaging part of the lecture, as it allowed them to interact with their peers, meet new people, and engage in discussions in a more intimate setting. Many appreciated the opportunity to work in smaller groups, which they found to be a more effective way to communicate and collaborate with their classmates. The use of breakout rooms also provided a sense of comfort and familiarity, allowing students to feel more at ease and connected with their peers.
input:
I found the class to be interesting and interactive. I enjoyed meeting fellow students as this helped me to feel more comfortable and overall welcome in the class.
The class activity was interesting. 
Getting to know the professor and the peers
I loved the breakout rooms and the chance to meet new people. I also found the activity we did very interesting as well because I didn't expect the questions you asked us afterwards to be so thought-provoking. 
I liked how we went over what the course would look like and who we could contact for help.
I found the breakout groups to be the most interesting. I had never used them before so it was a good learning experience.
I enjoyed the breakout sessions. They really allowed me to talk more in-depth with specific people, rather than just watching the instructor. It made the whole experience a lot more initiating and interactive. 
The people I met in my group 
I thought that the layout of the course was interesting and the activity of drawing our view of an engineer was very interesting. The layout is 4 main projects and I thought that it was cool to be in that format rather than many smaller projects. The drawing was interesting because it made you look to the future.
The most interesting thing I found was the logistics of the class and how we are supposed to complete projects
 I found the most interesting thing in today's class was the discussion we had with our breakout group about how engineers in 2030 would be like.
 I found the understanding of how the general aspects of the class would work to be interesting in today's class.

 The interaction between the class, as well as what the content of the course is going to be. The breakout rooms were useful in getting to know the other students.

 using the breakout rooms and getting to meet other people.

To improve student understanding, it is recommended to provide more detailed explanations and examples for complex equations, clearer instructions for in-class assignments, and additional guidance on deriving mathematical models from data, especially for the laminar approach.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the discussion on engineering failures to be engaging and informative, with many highlighting the importance of attention to detail, good communication, and ethics in engineering. The Taum Sauk reservoir case study was a notable example, with students appreciating the analysis of the various factors that contributed to its failure, including negligence, lack of proper ethics, and oversights in design and land surveying. Students also appreciated the opportunity to work in groups and analyze real-world examples of engineering failures, which helped to illustrate the potential consequences of errors and the importance of learning from past mistakes.
input:
I enjoyed the discussion about engineering failures. I wish we had spent more time on discussing what choices resulted in the failures.
I found the engineering failures for the Taum Sauk reservoir to be an insightful example of how engineering projects can go badly based on negligence and lack of proper ethics by engineers involved in orchestrating it.
What I enjoyed most in this class was working on the project with my peers.
Learning about different engineering disasters and going into detail about how things went wrong was interesting

input:
It was all pretty clear, there wasn't much that I was confused about in this lecture
Everything was clear over the material that was discussed in class
What was confusing about this class, was how are we supposed to know if to include something we think is a  constraint is one for the company too?
The expectations for Assignment 10 were very unclear. During our studio time it took us a very long time to understand what exactly was "due" on the technical brief.
Today, I thought that the instructions for assignment 10 were confusing, especially involving the mathematical modeling for the project.
I was confused around the in class activity. How do you find peer reviewed or reliable sources on more general information. All papers seem to be on specific topics.
The Taum Sauk upper reservoir sketch for the tech brief was confusing because it did not detail  what the sketch was entailing when it came to calculations.
Parts 4 and 5 of assignment A10 are very confusing. My team and I have all read the “background/technical content” several times. We are still unclear on how to draw the visual models using the Laminar Approach. I believe that going over the Laminar Approach and doing an example would be extremely beneficial to all teams. 
I didn't really understand which sources were acceptable for this class. I know which sources are more reliable than others, but not which degree of reliability is acceptable for class assignments. 
I didn't have enough time for the in class activity. Also what we were supposed to do in the second  time in breakout rooms wasn't completely clear to me.
 i was having wifi problems at the beginning of the class so the discussion at the beginning was confusing.
 I was confused because on A10 we have to split up the work but you can't do parts 5-7 until 4 is done. 
 Everything explained was clear.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the concept of Payback Period/Payback Time to be the most interesting topic of the lecture, with many appreciating the simplicity and practicality of the formula for calculating it. They enjoyed applying the concept to real-life scenarios, such as determining whether a company's investment is worthwhile, and found it useful for their current project. The in-class activity and breakout groups were also well-received, as they provided a hands-on opportunity to practice calculating payback periods and understand the economic impact of investments.
input:
I found the calculation for how to find how long it will take for the company to get their investments back to be the most interesting.
Discussion with my peers 
capital investments and determining whether investment is good or bad
I actually found the capital investment formula to be very interesting in today's class.
that it was very simple to find the payback period. 
Nothing really stuck out in today's class. It was just the usual with a new formula to calculate with.
The breakout groups. Not that the large class discussion isn't interesting I just found the time for the breakout groups helped the group figure out what we have to do
Learning the specifics of how energy expenses are economically impactful was interesting. 
I doing interesting the relationship between energy purchased, consumed, and produced. This equation will definitely help my team during the project and we are able to see and understand how the factors relate. 
I found it interesting that companies have a capital investment payback period for upgrades on their products.

 That there is an explicit formula for the return of an investment.

Suggestions: 

1. To make the summary more concise, consider condensing the first sentence to focus on the topic and the students' interest in it, and then directly state the main points that follow. For example: "Students found the concept of Payback Period/Payback Time to be the most interesting topic of the lecture, with many appreciating its simplicity and practicality. They enjoyed applying the concept to real-life scenarios, such as determining whether a company's investment is worthwhile, and found it useful for their current project."

2. To further emphasize the students' engagement with the topic, consider highlighting specific phrases from their reflections that demonstrate their understanding and enthusiasm, such as "it's nice to see a simple formula for something that can be thought of as complex" or "it's an effective measure of if a capital investment is worthwhile or will result in negligible improvements." This will add more depth to the summary and show that students are actively engaging with the material.

3. To improve the clarity of the summary, consider breaking it into two separate sentences to better distinguish between the students' interest in the topic and their appreciation for the in-class activity and breakout groups. For example: "Students found the concept of Payback Period/Payback Time to be the most interesting topic of the lecture, with many appreciating its simplicity and practicality. The in-class activity and breakout groups were also well-received, providing a hands-on opportunity to practice calculating payback periods and understand the economic impact of investments."

They enjoyed applying the concept to real-life scenarios, such as determining whether a company's investment is worthwhile, and found it useful for their current project. Many students appreciated the hands-on opportunity to practice calculating payback periods through the in-class activity and breakout groups, which helped them understand the economic impact of investments and feel more confident in their abilities.

The in-class activity of calculating the carbon emissions of their vehicles was particularly engaging, with many students finding it surprising to learn about the amount of CO2 produced by their cars. The discussion on design trade-offs and the importance of considering the environmental effects of their projects resonated with students, highlighting the relevance of carbon footprints to their future careers as engineers.

Suggestions:

1. Emphasize the students' surprise and realization about the significant impact of their daily activities on the environment, specifically the amount of CO2 produced by their cars, to further highlight the importance of considering carbon footprints in engineering projects.
2. Consider combining the points about the in-class activity and the discussion on design trade-offs to create a more cohesive sentence, such as "The in-class activity of calculating the carbon emissions of their vehicles, which revealed surprising results, reinforced the importance of considering design trade-offs and the environmental effects of their projects."
3. Use more precise language to describe the students' reactions, such as "Many students were surprised and engaged by the calculation of their car's carbon emissions" instead of "many students found it surprising to learn about the amount of CO2 produced by their cars."

pred: SUMMARY: Students expressed varying levels of clarity regarding the assignments, particularly Assignment 5 and Assignment 8. Many students found the explanations for these assignments to be confusing, citing a lack of detail and clarity in the instructions. Some students struggled with understanding how to handle missing data in Assignment 8, while others were unclear about the expectations for submitting data for Assignment 5. Additionally, students requested more practice with probability and z-score concepts, as well as more examples and explanations for using Excel to analyze data.
input:
Discussing the calculus formula for finding the area was a bit confusing. I would've liked a bit more information about it, and how it works.
the assignment number 5
I felt all the details were clear during this class
One thing that was confusing about today's class was how to switch the x-axis to a percentage from a numerical value in the skittle example. I was just confused as to if there is an easy way to change it or if that is just something you have to calculate and then set as a new type of data. 
We needed more details about what we were using the class' skittle data for. There is already a PDF of skittle data for Assignment 08 so what was our data for?
Today I thought that assignment 8 was confusing. I was struggling with how to handle the missing data in excel.
How was the data on people age gathered from Excel? I thought that many of the birth dates where redundant.
Bike share group project.
The z score was roughly explained

How probability and z score are related. Also, can we please go over some examples of how to fill in missing data. My team is struggling on question one on assignment 8. Could we go over some examples of how to fill in missing data? 
 I feel A08 needed more explanation. When we talk in class about assigments ensemble we do that superficially but when we need to work on them on out own or with our team I start to feel a little bit lost.
 What we were supposed to be doing in the first breakout room was confusing because we were just sitting around for most of it and we didn't know what to do.
 Nothing was confusing today during class
 I think I need more practice with the concepts of probability and standard distribution of data.
 I didn't understand where the .06 value for the standard deviation came from
 The due dates are alittle confusing in bright space so maybe a better expiration on how to find things better 
 The explanation for what to do for assignment 08
 How to decide how similar distribution s are to the normal distribution and when to use the z-score. 
 I wasn't really confused today
 Assignment 5 because we did not go over it.
 The material for A08 seemed like it needed a little extra detail since the module as a whole doesn't seem to have much discription.
 I find probability in general confusing. 
 I felt like the explanation regarding the process of finding the probability of a skittles bag having over 27% yellow skittles. 
 The z score was a little bit confusing. I did watch the module prior to class, however it still throws me off. I understand the concept behind it but feel I would like more practice and work with it. 
 I would've appreciated more time spent on the expectations for each assignment, such as a read through of the instructions and the expectation for each point.
 Something I found unclear about today's lecture was how the z number was used in the calculus equation for area under the curve.
 Nothing, class was great as usual
 Assignment 8 was confusing to understand where each part was because of explanation.
 I was confused on what to do with the missing dat is assignment 8 because we did not want to just omit the data. 
 Today's class was very detailed and does not need any extra explanation

Many students also expressed confusion about how to switch the x-axis to a percentage from a numerical value in the histogram, and some found the instructions for the histogram rule of thumb unclear. Additionally, some students felt that the explanation of the z-score concept was not thorough enough and would benefit from more practice and examples.

Suggestions:

1.  Provide more detailed explanations of the z-score calculation and its application to the Skittles example, including examples of how to use it to find the probability of a Skittles bag having over 27% yellow candies.
2.  Offer more guidance on how to switch the x-axis to a percentage from a numerical value in the histogram, including examples of how to do this in Excel.
3.  Clarify the instructions for the histogram rule of thumb, including how to determine the number of bins and how to apply the rule to the Skittles data.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the concept of biomimicry, or using nature to create solutions to design problems, to be a unique and interesting approach to problem-solving. Many students were engaged by the examples presented in class, such as the use of snake skin to inspire new materials and the adaptation of beetle shells to create strong, force-resistant materials. The process of brainstorming and idea generation was also a highlight, with students appreciating the variety of methods and techniques used to stimulate creativity. Overall, the topic of biomimicry sparked curiosity and enthusiasm among students, with many seeing its potential applications in engineering and design.

pred: SUMMARY: Students generally found today's class on Project Logistics to be straightforward and easy to follow, with minimal confusion. However, there were some areas that caused uncertainty, particularly regarding the scope of background information, the process of incorporating stakeholders, and the distinction between criteria and constraints. pred: SUMMARY: Students found the in-class activity and discussion on Assignment 17 to be engaging and helpful, particularly in clarifying expectations and understanding the importance of evaluating pros and cons in design projects. Many appreciated the opportunity to work with their teams, generate ideas, and analyze the strengths and weaknesses of different solutions. The use of real-world examples, such as the French press and Keurig coffee makers, was also seen as a valuable learning experience. Students recognized the significance of considering pros and cons in the design process, noting its application in narrowing down product weaknesses and strengths, and optimizing the design process.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the topic of carbon emissions to be a significant and engaging aspect of the lecture, with many expressing interest in learning about the environmental impact of their daily activities and the importance of considering carbon footprints in engineering projects. The in-class activity of calculating the CO2 emissions of their cars was a highlight, with many students finding it surprising and eye-opening to see the actual amount of emissions produced by their vehicles. The discussion on design trade-offs and the concept of trade-offs in general was also a point of interest, with students recognizing its relevance to their future careers as engineers. Overall, the topic of carbon emissions sparked a sense of awareness and responsibility among students, with many expressing a desire to learn more about the topic and its implications.

pred: SUMMARY: Students expressed confusion regarding the prototyping process, particularly in relation to testing and creating prototypes without physical materials. Many students struggled to understand how to effectively test their designs, especially when using CAD software, and felt that more guidance on testing protocols and experiment design would be beneficial. Some students also found it challenging to determine the level of detail required for their prototypes and were unsure about the feasibility of testing virtual prototypes.
input:
Today's class was little confusing and I didn't need any extra details.
Prototyping 
The prototype section, specifically testing, is VERY confusing. My team is unsure how we are supposed to test our prototypes, especially if they are created using CAD software. Without purchasing materials, I'm unsure what could be used to create and test our solutions.
How detailed we need to be in our prototypes. 
Finding ways to develop a prototype for our idea 
I was confused about how to make a prototype for one of our designs originally. 
Nothing was confusing in today's class
I didn't get what materials i should use for prototype 
Something that could use more details in today's class was the schedule with our new reading day, because you went over it kind of quick and I didn't catch all the dates. 
We as a team found it difficult to find out not only how we would build a prototype, and how to test it. Unless we make them individually, physical prototypes aren't really feasible due to our separation. Additionally we couldn't figure out doable but also reliable ways to test our prototypes. 
 I thought the most difficult aspect of today's class was determining how to prototype our ideas to show the functionality of them.
 How we should develop a testing protocol is unclear. I don't remember going over it in the video modules and it isn't explained in the technical brief or assignment 17 instructions. I think going through an example of a testing protocol for the smart recycling bins would have been beneficial to the teams' understanding of what a testing protocol is and how to develop an effective one. 
 The confusing part about today was figuring out how my group will make the prototypes and test them in life. This was confusing for us because one of our team members is off campus, so we need to figure out how to test the prototypes and how we are making them.
 Everything made sense into today's class. But I wish there was more explanation to the ways we could create prototypes if the software option was not available to use. Other than that, everything made sense.
 I found it interesting the different types of modeling that could be used
 What was confusing was how the prototypes the groups create will be tested. My group was having a hard time understanding how this would be done virtually and with models of our design (given we don't have the ability to make real models of our prototype with the materials we wanted)
 The details for the assignment was confusing to me. The team was confused on what CAD software to use and some of the other elements of the assignment. I think after the slides are posted we will be able to review it and answer our questions.
 A confusing thing was the building of prototypes. It was confusing because of the use of materials that aren't easily accessible. 
 I am unsure of when A18 is due because bright space still has it down for next Friday. But it was said that we will work on it next Friday in class as well.
 I think prototyping in general is a bit confusing, at least to me. I dont really know how should I approach prototype making. 
 It was a little confusing how we are supposed to test our prototypes without actually having physical prototypes. My group is doing CAD models, and are having difficulty determining how we are going to effectively test our models, as they aren't really something we can just go out and test.
 How we can test our ideas was confusing because our ideas must be used on such a large sclae and we have such limited materials.
 I did not completely understand how through our prototypes had to be.
 Nothing was confusing or hard to understand. Everything was very clear 
 I haven't been exposed to a lot of the prototyping methods like CAD, so I feel like it might be pretty tough to learn something like that in the next week. 
 I thought it was confusing when we talked about the surveys because I was unsure if they counted as part of the prototype testing process. 
 I wasn't confused about anything today. We just had a few hiccups with our last grade and discussed with the TA what we got wrong.
 I thought that the discussion of the importance of prototyping was interesting. It had good information and was easy to follow.
 How we should go about testing any physical model that we create
 I would've appreciated if we went over some examples of what a strong experiment looks like versus a weak one. Additionally, how we could measure if our experiments were successful.
 I am confused on how to exactly test my virtual prototypes. 
 Knowing how to prototype virtually can be difficult and confusing at times, and having useful accessible materials is not always possible.
 One thing that was confusing about today's class was how are we supposed to test our design on a virtual platform if the platform only allows you to design not test? Or do you have to make the physical prototype and then test?
 I found it confusing how we are going to create a prototype for some of our designs
 I was a bit confused still on how detailed we needed to make our prototypes especially since we don't always have the resources
 What options we would have for making prototypes. If there were things we are not allowed to do on campus that would limit what we can do. 
 How in depth the experiments should be
 I was confused as to how to actually test a prototype. 
 Nothing today 
 nothing was confusing
 The research method and way of testing was confusing. Nothing was clarified.
 More details about the testing procedure section would be helpful 
 Thinking of prototypes while most of our ideas had to do with the road was confusing
 Nothing was confusing today. There was nothing to be confusing though because everything explained had to do with methods of prototyping.
 We only had one confusing point during the lecture, we didn't understand if it was supposed to be 3 different designs or 3 different ideas prototyped. This was solved however in our breakout room 
 Nothing was confusing today! Professor Menekse explained the prototyping process well, which helped us to discuss ways to make prototype our designs
 Everything was clear and easy to understand
 How we should make a prototype that we can also test, for example cad models would be hard to test for a18.
 Nothing
 the specifications of assignment 18 needed a bit more clarification, but otherwise all was pretty clear 
 I was confused by the way we can implement questions for the concrete details

pred: SUMMARY: Students generally found the CAD aspect of the lecture confusing, particularly when it came to testing and developing prototypes. Many students struggled to understand how to effectively test their CAD models, especially when physical prototypes were not feasible due to limited resources or team members being off-campus. There was also confusion about the level of detail required in the prototypes and the availability of materials for testing. Some students felt that more examples or clarification on testing protocols and experiment design would have been helpful to better understand the process.
input:
Today's class was little confusing and I didn't need any extra details.
Prototyping 
The prototype section, specifically testing, is VERY confusing. My team is unsure how we are supposed to test our prototypes, especially if they are created using CAD software. Without purchasing materials, I'm unsure what could be used to create and test our solutions.
How detailed we need to be in our prototypes. 
Finding ways to develop a prototype for our idea 
I was confused about how to make a prototype for one of our designs originally. 
Nothing was confusing in today's class
I didn't get what materials i should use for prototype 
Something that could use more details in today's class was the schedule with our new reading day, because you went over it kind of quick and I didn't catch all the dates. 
We as a team found it difficult to find out not only how we would build a prototype, and how to test it. Unless we make them individually, physical prototypes aren't really feasible due to our separation. Additionally we couldn't figure out doable but also reliable ways to test our prototypes. 
 I thought the most difficult aspect of today's class was determining how to prototype our ideas to show the functionality of them.
 How we should develop a testing protocol is unclear. I don't remember going over it in the video modules and it isn't explained in the technical brief or assignment 17 instructions. I think going through an example of a testing protocol for the smart recycling bins would have been beneficial to the teams' understanding of what a testing protocol is and how to develop an effective one. 
 The confusing part about today was figuring out how my group will make the prototypes and test them in life. This was confusing for us because one of our team members is off campus, so we need to figure out how to test the prototypes and how we are making them.
 Everything made sense into today's class. But I wish there was more explanation to the ways we could create prototypes if the software option was not available to use. Other than that, everything made sense.
 I found it interesting the different types of modeling that could be used
 What was confusing was how the prototypes the groups create will be tested. My group was having a hard time understanding how this would be done virtually and with models of our design (given we don't have the ability to make real models of our prototype with the materials we wanted)
 The details for the assignment was confusing to me. The team was confused on what CAD software to use and some of the other elements of the assignment. I think after the slides are posted we will be able to review it and answer our questions.
 A confusing thing was the building of prototypes. It was confusing because of the use of materials that aren't easily accessible. 
 I am unsure of when A18 is due because bright space still has it down for next Friday. But it was said that we will work on it next Friday in class as well.
 I think prototyping in general is a bit confusing, at least to me. I dont really know how should I approach prototype making. 
 It was a little confusing how we are supposed to test our prototypes without actually having physical prototypes. My group is doing CAD models, and are having difficulty determining how we are going to effectively test our models, as they aren't really something we can just go out and test.
 How we can test our ideas was confusing because our ideas must be used on such a large sclae and we have such limited materials.
 I did not completely understand how through our prototypes had to be.
 Nothing was confusing or hard to understand. Everything was very clear 
 I haven't been exposed to a lot of the prototyping methods like CAD, so I feel like it might be pretty tough to learn something like that in the next week. 
 I thought it was confusing when we talked about the surveys because I was unsure if they counted as part of the prototype testing process. 
 I wasn't confused about anything today. We just had a few hiccups with our last grade and discussed with the TA what we got wrong.
 I thought that the discussion of the importance of prototyping was interesting. It had good information and was easy to follow.
 How we should go about testing any physical model that we create
 I would've appreciated if we went over some examples of what a strong experiment looks like versus a weak one. Additionally, how we could measure if our experiments were successful.
 I am confused on how to exactly test my virtual prototypes. 
 Knowing how to prototype virtually can be difficult and confusing at times, and having useful accessible materials is not always possible.
 One thing that was confusing about today's class was how are we supposed to test our design on a virtual platform if the platform only allows you to design not test? Or do you have to make the physical prototype and then test?
 I found it confusing how we are going to create a prototype for some of our designs
 I was a bit confused still on how detailed we needed to make our prototypes especially since we don't always have the resources
 What options we would have for making prototypes. If there were things we are not allowed to do on campus that would limit what we can do. 
 How in depth the experiments should be
 I was confused as to how to actually test a prototype. 
 Nothing today 
 nothing was confusing
 The research method and way of testing was confusing. Nothing was clarified.
 More details about the testing procedure section would be helpful 
 Thinking of prototypes while most of our ideas had to do with the road was confusing
 Nothing was confusing today. There was nothing to be confusing though because everything explained had to do with methods of prototyping.
 We only had one confusing point during the lecture, we didn't understand if it was supposed to be 3 different designs or 3 different ideas prototyped. This was solved however in our breakout room 
 Nothing was confusing today! Professor Menekse explained the prototyping process well, which helped us to discuss ways to make prototype our designs
 Everything was clear and easy to understand
 How we should make a prototype that we can also test, for example cad models would be hard to test for a18.
 Nothing
 the specifications of assignment 18 needed a bit more clarification, but otherwise all was pretty clear 
 I was confused by the way we can implement questions for the concrete details

suggestion:
Summary: Students found the CAD aspect of the lecture confusing, particularly when it came to testing and developing prototypes. Many students struggled to understand how to effectively test their CAD models, especially when physical prototypes were not feasible due to limited resources or team members being off-campus. There was also confusion about the level of detail required in the prototypes and the availability of materials for testing. Some students felt that more examples or clarification on testing protocols and experiment design would have been helpful to better understand the process.

Suggestions:

1. Emphasize the importance of testing protocols and provide more concrete examples of how to develop and implement them, especially for CAD models, to alleviate confusion and provide a clear understanding of the testing process.
2. Clarify the level of detail required in prototypes and provide guidance on how to determine the necessary level of detail based on the specific project requirements and available resources.
3. Address the issue of limited resources and provide suggestions for alternative methods of testing CAD models, such as virtual testing or simulations, to make the process more feasible for students with limited access to physical materials.
refined_pred: REFINED SUMMARY: Students found the CAD aspect of the lecture challenging, particularly in understanding how to effectively test and develop prototypes, especially when physical prototypes were not feasible due to limited resources or team members being off-campus. Confusion also arose regarding the level of detail required in prototypes and the availability of materials for testing. To address these concerns, providing more concrete examples of testing protocols and experiment design, especially for CAD models, would be beneficial. Additionally, clarifying the necessary level of detail in prototypes and offering alternative testing methods, such as virtual testing or simulations, could help alleviate confusion and support students in understanding the testing process.

pred: SUMMARY: Students generally found the groupwork and brainstorming aspects of the lecture productive and engaging, with many reporting that they were able to get a lot done. However, some students expressed confusion about the application of biomimicry to the project, with many unsure of how to incorporate it into their ideas. Additionally, some students felt that the instructions for the A17 assignment were unclear, and that more guidance on the brainstorming process and what constitutes a relevant idea would be helpful.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the topic of problem scoping to be engaging and relevant, particularly in the context of starting their own design project. Many appreciated the opportunity to learn about the differences between novice and professional engineers, as well as the importance of stakeholder relations and end-user considerations. The process of developing problem statements and criteria was also highlighted as a key aspect of problem scoping, with students enjoying the hands-on experience of working in groups to identify and analyze potential solutions. Overall, students found the topic to be interesting and applicable to real-world scenarios, with many expressing enthusiasm for the upcoming design project and the opportunity to apply their knowledge in a practical way.
input:
starting our own design project 
I found the client stakeholder relations to be very interesting as well as the differences between a anovice and professional engineer.
Differences between client and end user
I liked working on problem scoping and developing ways to measure constraints and criteria
The project that was assigned to us for the final design was very interesting especially when we went into breakout rooms and discussed it
The issue of improving campus safety sounds interesting.
Learning about problem scoping and the upcoming design project
That we are creating our own ideas to a problem we are given.
I found working on the in class assignment to be most interesting. 
The most interesting part about todays class was starting a new project to work on with my team
 The most interesting part of today's class was how engineers work effectively with problem scoping to properly define a project. 
 I did not realize that we had been slowly incorporating different aspects of design into our assignments 
 Group time was very helpful to assign roles for the new project 
 starting a new project was the most interesting today
 It was interesting to start a new unit and continue forward w our content
 The project objective is arguably better than the other class's.
 What I found most interesting about today's class was the analytical skills that are required to design your own solution to a problem. 
 Before today's class I was really confused on who a stakeholder was. Today's class really clarified that for me. It was interesting to have it clarified bc I'd been confused on it for so long. 
 I found the fact that stakeholders, clients, and end-user can change based on perspective of the project to be very interesting. Based on what you're doing, you may have different people or groups for each of them.
 I thought it was interesting when we were talking about the difference between experienced and novice designers. 
 Design issues as a whole
 I found the research during problem scoping interesting.
 I think the idea behind the design project is interesting because it gives us important experience problem scoping as opposed to looking at specific data and saying “this needs to change”.
 Using what we have done so far, in regards to previous projects, is how we are going to complete this new projects. Seeing how we incorporate all of our knowledge into this final work will be interesting 
 I found it interesting to learn about the new project and work with the others in my group to accomplish what is due for friday.
 What I found most interesting in today's class was how a client or end user was a stakeholder always but a stakeholder could be a client or end user, but is not necessarily always one. 
 It was interesting to start a new project and start to scope out solutions. Our team wants to come up with a realistic solution
 I think it is interesting to learn about the design process and to know what to do to act as a more experienced engineer/designer.

pred: SUMMARY: Students generally found the concept of DLBs (Dictionary Learning Bases) to be confusing, particularly in terms of implementation and runtime analysis. They struggled to understand the use of linked lists in DLBs, questioning whether each linked list points to both sibling and child nodes. Additionally, students were unclear about the specifics of Multi-way RSTs, including the origin of the number 256 and how to draw out DLB trees with siblings. They also found it challenging to keep track of runtimes and variable meanings in runtime analyses.

Summary: Students found strong induction challenging to understand, particularly in determining the number of base cases and applying the concept to abstract problems. They struggled with the process of transitioning from making a statement to applying it, and some questioned the necessity of strong induction when it doesn't seem more powerful than weak induction. Suggestions:
1. Emphasize the importance of understanding the specific characteristics of strong induction, such as the need for multiple base cases, to differentiate it from weak induction. This could be done by highlighting examples where strong induction is necessary, such as when the statement to be proven is not true for the first few cases.
2. Provide more concrete examples of strong induction in action, focusing on the process of determining the number of base cases and how to apply the concept to abstract problems. This could help students see the practical application of strong induction and make it more tangible.
3. Address the misconception that strong induction is not more powerful than weak induction by highlighting the specific scenarios where strong induction is preferred, such as when the statement to be proven has multiple base cases or when the inductive step is complex. This could help students understand the value of strong induction and when to use it over weak induction.
refined_pred: REFINED SUMMARY: Students found strong induction challenging to understand, particularly in determining the number of base cases and applying the concept to abstract problems. They struggled with the process of transitioning from making a statement to applying it, and some questioned the necessity of strong induction when it doesn't seem more powerful than weak induction. To clarify, strong induction requires multiple base cases, which is crucial in differentiating it from weak induction. Examples of strong induction in action, such as proving a statement with multiple initial exceptions, can help students grasp the concept. Strong induction is preferred when the inductive step is complex or when the statement has multiple base cases, making it a valuable tool in mathematical proofs.

SUMMARY: Students struggled to understand various concepts related to current, including determining direction through Lenz's law, interpreting units in circuit problems, and applying equations for finding current in RL circuits. They also found it challenging to distinguish between the behavior of inductors and resistors, and how inductors behave in circuits. Additionally, students were confused about the relationship between current, frequency, and oscillations, particularly in the context of inductors and capacitors.

Suggestions:
1. To improve the summary, it would be beneficial to break down the concepts into more specific categories, such as "Understanding Lenz's Law", "Interpreting Units in Circuit Problems", and "Applying Equations for RL Circuits", to provide a clearer overview of the students' struggles.
2. Consider highlighting the most common points of confusion, such as the relationship between current, frequency, and oscillations, and the behavior of inductors and resistors, to provide a more focused summary.
3. To make the summary more concise, it would be helpful to eliminate redundant phrases, such as "including" and "particularly", and use more direct language to convey the students' struggles, such as "Students struggled to understand Lenz's law" instead of "determining direction through Lenz's law".

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the in-class demonstrations to be a valuable learning tool, particularly the visual representations of phasors, resonance, and the relationships between inductors, capacitors, and resistors. The use of a projected meter to demonstrate resonance in a circuit helped students understand the concept of frequency. The oscilloscope was also praised for increasing understanding of a circuit at resonance. Additionally, students appreciated the visual aids such as sin waves and graphs, which made it easier to grasp complex concepts like phase angles and the differences between inductance and capacitance.

SUMMARY: Students found the concept of phasers and graphs to be engaging and helpful in understanding AC circuits. The visual representation of phasors and demonstrations of resonance in a circuit effectively illustrated frequency's impact on circuit behavior. Students appreciated the use of graphs and equations to visualize and solve problems, and found practice problems and word problems to be helpful in solidifying their understanding. The oscilloscope's visualization of circuit behavior at resonance was a highlight, providing a tangible representation of abstract concepts.

Suggestions:
1. Consider rephrasing "engaging and helpful" to be more specific, such as "clarifying and intuitive", to better reflect the students' experiences.
2. Emphasize the role of visual aids, such as the oscilloscope and phasor graphs, in making complex concepts more accessible to students, e.g. "The use of visual aids, such as the oscilloscope and phasor graphs, greatly enhanced students' understanding of AC circuits."
3. Highlight the students' surprise and interest in the relationship between resistance and current at resonance, e.g. "Students were particularly interested in the counterintuitive relationship between resistance and current at resonance, where a circuit can have significant current without resistance."
refined_pred: REFINED SUMMARY: Students found the concept of phasers and graphs to be clarifying and intuitive in understanding AC circuits. The visual representation of phasors and demonstrations of resonance in a circuit effectively illustrated frequency's impact on circuit behavior. The use of visual aids, such as the oscilloscope and phasor graphs, greatly enhanced students' understanding of AC circuits. Students were particularly interested in the counterintuitive relationship between resistance and current at resonance, where a circuit can have significant current without resistance. Practice problems and word problems were also found to be helpful in solidifying their understanding of the material.
